awd_titl_txt: Scaffold-based Synthetic Models of Mono-Iron Hydrogenase: Structure and Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Prof. Michael Rose at the University of Texas at Austin to investigate the role of the iron center in an enzyme called mono-iron hydrogenase. This enzyme is molecule important for the capture of carbon dioxide (CO2) in methanogens, which are single cell microorganisms that can be found for example in the human gut and in wetlands. These organisms are very efficient at transforming dihydrogen (H2) and CO2 from the environment in which they live into methane.  In contrast, artificial way to capture and transform H2 and CO2 are much less efficient. Furthermore while the enzymes, in particular mono-iron hydrogenase, utilize earth abundant metals like iron and nickel, many synthetic analogues of the enzymes utilize precious metals like platinum, iridium or palladium. The research of Professor Rose focuses on understanding how the mono-iron hydrogenase catalyzes the chemical transformation in the methanogens and applying this understanding to developing artificial catalysts as efficient as the enzyme. Professor Rose also participates in the outreach program called H2fromH2O. He interacts with high school students in the central Texas region to demonstrate the fundamental science, environmental impact and possible applications for splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen and derive energy from this process. The students who participate in the outreach program further disseminate such lessons to their families and communities.  This serves to raise awareness about the importance of developing renewable energy technologies. UT Austin undergraduates directly participate in the outreach efforts, become motivate to do research, and pursue job opportunities and graduate education in energy-related fields.

The available, iron-based synthetic (artificial) systems of a molecular nature do not replicate the speed and efficiency of the naturally occurring system. This research seeks to understand how components of the natural system can be incorporated to provide for enhanced reactivity. There are three technical approaches to understanding the H2-activating and hydride transfer activity of the enzyme mono-iron hydrogenase. First, synthetic model complexes are hybridized with protein hosts to determine the effect of the protein environment on the spectroscopic properties and functional reactivity of the model complexes (versus stand-alone metal complexes). Second, the "anthracene scaffold" strategy for assembling the biomimetic fac-CNS motif is modified with more flexible "anthranoid" scaffolds to investigate the role of protein-like flexibility of the donor arms on the reactivity of the model complexes. Third, the complexes contain a biomimetic pyridine moiety, which is hypothesized to assist in H2 heterolysis as a pendant base.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The University of Texas at Austin

por.por_cntn:
Summary

During the course of this 3-year award, our efforts focused on two thrusts: (i) the use of scaffold-based ligands to generate structural plus functional [Fe]-H2ase mimics, and (ii) the synthesis of nitrogenase clusters based on authentic iron-carbide motifs.

Intellectual Merit

To the first end (i), we determined that scaffold-based ligands consistently provide the fac-C,N,S donor motif found in the [Fe]-H2ase active site. The incorporation of a thiolate drives supports heterolytic H2 activation and drives hydride transfer to a biomimetic substrate, supporting the necessity of the iron-acyl-thiolate motif in the enzyme. Inclusion of an iron-methylene-acyl unit leads to ligand C-H deprotonation, which unexpectedly synergistically drives heterolytic H2 activation through a pendant base mechanism. Three PhD theses were completed (Dr Yae In Cho, Dr Zhu-Lin Samuel Xie, Dr Spencer Kerns) with support from this grant. Overall in this thrust, we demonstrate that we can replicate the activity of iron-based enzymes in small-molecule format, which is critical for developing earth-abundant catalysts for energy-relevant chemical transformations.

To the second end (ii), we have synthetically and spectroscopically studied iron-carbide clusters derived with sulfurs/sulfides/thiolates, as well as iron-carbide clusters modified with bio-relevant molybdenum. We showed that electrophilic sulfur sources (S2Cl2, or S8+oxidant) provide one-step synthetic access to first-in-class sulfide-iron-carbide clusters. We also generated Fe6, Fe5, Fe5Mo and Fe4Mo2 type carbide clusters for spectroscopic study. Via an international collaboration with Dr Serena DeBeer (MPI, Germany), it was demonstrated that the central carbide plays a critical role in allowing electronic communication among the coordinated metal centers.Two PhD theses (Dr Chris Joseph, Dr J Patrick Shupp) were completed with support from this grant. Overall, this work brings us one step closer to synthesizing functional mimics of the nitrogenase active site, which would allow for N2 reduction (i.e. fertilizer synthesis) at ambient temperature, pressure and pH.

Broader Impacts

Lastly, the broader impacts aims were achieved to disseminate and raise awareness regarding the importance of renewable fuel generation via the outreach program H2fromH2O. This program brings home-built electrolyzers for H2 generation from water to middle schools and high schools. This hands-on exercise has been fully integrated with the Texas TEAKS learning guidelines. The exercise is used in middle school to underscore the idea of renewable energies, and at the high school level to teach the concepts of stoichiometry, ideal gas law, decomposition, phases of matter and electrochemistry. Between 500-1000 young learners were engaged as a result of classroom activities, summer programs, online demos and campus exhibitions. More than 20 undergraduates participated in laboratory research, with the majority of participant matriculating to Chemistry PhD programs, Medical School, or Pharmacy programs.


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Michael J Rose

Images (1 of )
  • Using simple, designed "Two-Donor" ligands with phosphine or thioether donors, we determined that placement of the acyl-C donor trans to the "open site" for H2 binding is what enables H2 activation.
    Dr Yae In Cho
    Copyrighted
    Michael J Rose
    Phosphine/Thioether Coordination Location Determines H2 Reactivity at the Iron-Acyl Site
  • A synthetic model of [Fe]-H2ase catalyzes H2 activation and hydride transfer to a biomimetic substrate.
    Dr Spencer Kerns
    Copyrighted
    Michael J Rose
    Functional H2ase Mimic with Thiolate-Fe
  • We have used a systematic progression of synthetic models to achieve and understand the catalytic function of [Fe]-H2ase in small molecule format. We now thoroughly understand the precise role of the identity and location of each donor atom in the coordination sphere by using scaffold-based ligands.
    Dr Spencer Kerns
    Copyrighted
    Michael J Rose
    Bridge to Functional [Fe]-H2ase Mimics
  • Relevant to the nitrogen-fixing enzyme nitrogenase active site: There were no known sulfide-iron-carbide clusters prior to this report. Using an electrophilic sulfur source (S2Cl2), we derivatized a known iron-carbide-carbonyl cluster with 4-5 sulfur atoms.
    Dr Chris Joseph
    Copyrighted
    Michael J Rose
    One-step sulfide incorporation into Iron-Carbide Carbonyl clusters
  • We discovered that although this synthetic model of [Fe]-H2ase does activate H2 via a deprotonated iron-acylene unit, the subsequent hydride transfer proceeds through a non-biomimetic mechanism. The original Fe(II)-H unit reductively eliminates into an Fe(0) unit that proceeds to hydride tranfer.
    Dr Spencer Kerns
    Copyrighted
    Michael J Rose
    Biomimetic H2 activation followed by a Non-biomimetic hydride transfer mechanism
